Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story:
I was sweeping up stray hair when my phone buzzed. It was a text from my stepbrother: “Can you call? It’s urgent.” I ducked into the break room, heart pounding, and called him. His voice was shaky, barely holding together. He’d just gotten terrible news—something about our dad’s health. He needed me, and I could hear the tears in his voice. I wanted to drop everything, to be the sibling he could lean on, to listen and reassure him.

But as I tried to comfort him, the bell above the salon door chimed. Through the glass, I saw a young woman step in, clutching her purse, eyes darting nervously. My manager shot me a look: greet her, make her feel welcome. I was torn. My brother’s pain pressed on me, demanding my attention, but my job required me to put on a smile and help this anxious client feel at ease. My heart ached as I stood there, phone in hand, caught between being the supportive sibling my brother needed and the professional hairdresser my client expected.
